english.o_7_musi_s: Participation in the creation of the Piano Melodias and Piano Partiruras courses by Musihacks.
english.w_28_1p:
With an approximate duration of 20 minutes and for a large ad hoc percussion group for a space, it is inspired by the myth of the Tower of Babel. This work aims to explore the translation of the same sound gesture in 3 instrumental groups.

The first group, with a pointillistic and energetic discourse, is made up of 3 percussionists with bongos, who lead the discourse. The second group is made up of different pitched percussion instruments, which, capturing the resonance of the bongos, convert it into a harmonic spectrum, translating the original material. Finally, the last group, the largest, gathers all the sonority and translates it in a spatialized manner.
english.w_28_2p: The work has been conceived for its presentation at RiberALZ 2024, and is dedicated to the large percussion group participating in the project and suited to the specific space, taking advantage of all the sonic capabilities it offers.
english.w_28_w: This work has been performed at the "RiverAlz II 2024" festival in the concert of 29.07.24.
english.w_29_1p: This work explores the relationship between the performer's voice and the instruments as some rhythmic percussion arts do, like Konnakol, which involves assigning syllables to the typical strokes of the tabla to study and interpret its music. In “To-kà,” this resource is also used as a rhythmic and timbral scenic element. The instruments have been chosen considering the timbral coherence with the voice but also as a reminder of those tribal music styles that use these vocal techniques.
english.w_29_2p: Regarding the visuals, two techniques have been used. On one hand, public domain samurai films have been employed, and on the other hand, the faces of the performers have been superimposed in 3D. Although there is a narrative thread, the main goal of the video is not to tell a story, but for the audience to discover a type of cinema different from Western cinema. Scanning the performers' faces is a current trend in contemporary music to personalize the visual content with the same performers. In today's terms, a customized version. In this case, the characters sometimes transform into the performers themselves.
english.w_29_w: This work has been created for the Alxarq trio, who were the first to perform it. It has also received financial support from the Instituto Valenciano de Cultura in the 2024 music promotion grants.
english.w_30_1p:
This work investigates the soundscapes of a sextet within a discourse where fragmented polyphony coexists with contemporary harmonic treatments, placing significant emphasis on the spectral and gestural aspects of the piece.

"La ecuación del calor" offers a modern vision where pointillistic approaches, rhythmic variety, and timbral modulations are inspired by the eponymous equation. This equation describes the distribution of heat (or temperature variations) in a region over time. Moreover, it led to the discovery of the Fourier series, essential for the harmonic analysis of a sound.
english.w_30_2p: Although there is scientific inspiration, the organic discourse has been designed to favor both the musician and the listener, aiming for an enjoyable experience for both after a process involving micro-phrasing, phrasing, and spatialization, among others.
english.w_30_w: This work was awarded the 2nd prize in the 35th edition of the Premio Jóvenes Compositores 2024 - SGAE CNDM in 2024.
english.ng_1:
These alterations are considered approximate microtonal changes.

The alterations follow traditional conventions. Courtesy accidentals are added throughout the piece due to the potential difficulty and complexity of reading.
english.ng_1_ex: They are executed with slight detuning, achieved through an embouchure adjustment in wind instruments or a change of position or a bend in string instruments, for example.
english.ng_2:
These alterations are considered exact microtonal changes.

The alterations follow traditional conventions. Courtesy accidentals are added throughout the piece due to the potential difficulty and complexity of reading.
english.ng_2_ex:
They are executed by changing to a specific position.

As represented in the image: -150 cents (-3/4 tone), -50 cents (-1/4 tone), +50 cents (+1/4 tone), +150 cents (+3/4 tone).
english.ng_3:
As high as possible.

The size (big) of the triangle matters, as does its direction.
english.ng_3_ex: It is played as high as possible on the instrument. If necessary, extended techniques such as overpressure or others should be used.
english.ng_4:
Tremolo indication.

It is usually marked with the corresponding note where the tremolo is performed.
english.ng_4_ex: It is important to consider the speed of the tremolo, which is indicated by the notation. Tremolos can be fast, normal, or slow. They can also transition from fast to slow or slow to fast.
english.ng_5:
Invisible noteheads.

Only the stems are kept to indicate rhythm.
english.ng_5_ex:
If the note is repeated from the previous one, the notehead is removed to clarify the score's readability. However, sometimes it is included for clarity. This is designed so the performer focuses on the gesture rather than the note (as it is the same).

Sometimes this notation also can indicate an approximate pitch.
english.ng_6: The niente sign (the nothing) is indicated with a circle at the end of a decrescendo or the beginning of a crescendo. It implies ending or starting the sound gesture without sound.
english.ng_6_ex: It is a gestural indication. The difference from a silence lies in the gesture and the performer's attitude. In the case of niente, it must be active. In both cases, there should be no sound.
english.ng_7: This clarifying time notation can be indicated without a continuous line, meaning it lasts as long as the notation, or with a continuous line for greater precision.
english.ng_7_ex: It does not imply sound. It clarifies how long the event lasts. This notation is used when the base notation is ambiguous or could cause confusion.
english.ng_8: Dynamics in parentheses are presented this way due to their difficult execution caused by the technique at that moment.
english.ng_8_ex:
They signify an approximation and gestural intention that may not be reflected in the physical amplitude of the sound but are conveyed visually.

Also, depending on the context, it can also serve to remember the dynamics.
english.ng_9: This technique is known as dry or open slap. The resulting sound is a percussive and unpitched sonority.
english.ng_9_ex: The sound production varies depending on the type of embouchure and/or reed, but the result should always be the same. The fingering of the referenced note must be maintained because, even though the sound is unpitched, the position affects the final result.
english.ng_10: This technique is known as closed slap. The resulting sound is a semi-percussive sonority with a tone.
english.ng_10_ex: The sound production varies depending on the type of embouchure and/or reed, but the result should always be the same.
english.ng_11: The notation refers to percussive sounds produced by striking the instrument's keys.
english.ng_11_ex: It is approximate and does not define which keys to articulate at each moment. This will be the performer's decision based on the dynamics to which the technique is subjected.
english.ng_12: This technique is known as bisbigliando or timbral trill. The resulting sound is a micro-trill or micro-tremolo.
english.ng_12_ex: If the key to execute the technique is not specified, it will be the performer's responsibility to determine the most suitable key for the passage, considering the overall sonority of that moment.
english.ng_13:
The Teeth Tone or biting the reed produces a high and thin sound.

It is usually notated with an upward triangle (as high as possible) to indicate the sound should be high.
english.ng_13_ex: The sound production varies depending on the type of embouchure and/or reed.
english.ng_14: This is one of the techniques within the airy group. In this case, it consists of inhaling through the instrument without producing a tone.
english.ng_14_ex: Depending on the instrument, it may be necessary to remove the instrument's mouthpiece.
english.ng_15: This is one of the techniques within the airy group. In this case, it consists of exhaling through the instrument without producing a tone.
english.ng_15_ex: Depending on the instrument, it may be necessary to remove the instrument's mouthpiece.
english.ng_16:
Different gradations of airy sound and real tone.

As shown in the image: 0% tone - 100% air || 50% tone - 50% air || 100% tone - 0% air.
english.ng_16_ex: The sound production varies depending on the type of embouchure and/or reed. The airy tone usually corresponds to a relaxation in the embouchure.
english.ng_17:
The tongue ram is a sound gesture that produces a percussive-explosive sound.

The resulting sound is a major seventh below the fingered note.
english.ng_17_ex: It is produced by completely sealing the mouthpiece hole with the lips and forcefully pushing the tongue toward the mouthpiece hole.
english.ng_18: Whistle tones are produced when air moves slowly with very low pressure, like a soft exhalation. Vibrations occur on the lip plate rather than inside the tube, producing a high and thin sound.
english.ng_18_ex: In this case, they are open. This means that other notes appear from the same position without needing to change it.
english.ng_19: The harmonic cluster, strong whistle tone, or overtones produce a very energetic high-pitched sound.
english.ng_19_ex: It is produced by blowing strongly over the given position, generating a cluster of upper harmonics.
english.ng_20: Whistle tones are produced when air moves slowly with very low pressure, like a soft exhalation. Vibrations occur on the lip plate rather than inside the tube, producing a high and thin sound.
english.ng_20_ex: In this case, they are closed. This means the pitch is determined by position changes.
english.ng_21:
The Jet Whistle is a very loud sound similar to a glissando.

This technique always incorporates the sound's direction with a mini-glissando in the score.
english.ng_21_ex:
It is produced by completely sealing the mouthpiece hole with the lips and blowing a fast, high-pressure air stream through the flute.

For pitch changes, use the syllables "huuuu-eeee" for low to high and "heeee-uuu" for high to low.
english.ng_22: A visual indication referring to the flute's position relative to the mouth.
english.ng_22_ex: The upper indication corresponds to the flute being out of the mouth to produce other sonorities with the mouth, while the lower one represents the flute's ordinary position.
english.ng_23: The pizzicato sul ponticello is a pizzicato very close to the bridge, producing a drier sound.
english.ng_23_ex: This notation only affects the referenced note. It is not shown with traditional notation because the technique is maintained until it returns to "ord."
english.ng_24: This is the chosen notation for ordinary pizzicato.
english.ng_24_ex: This notation only affects the referenced note. It is not shown with traditional notation because the technique is maintained until it returns to "ord."
english.ng_25: Bartók pizzicato or Snap is a very strong pizzicato.
english.ng_25_ex: The sound is produced when the string hits the instrument's fingerboard, creating a very percussive tone similar to a whip.
english.ng_26: This technique uses the back of the bow (legno) combined with the gettato technique, producing a rough sonority.
english.ng_26_ex: These two techniques can be performed separately, but in this case, both are necessary to achieve the desired effect.
english.ng_27: Overpressure is a very typical resource for achieving aggressive and dense sonorities.
english.ng_27_ex: The image shows 100% overpressure (the thickest line) and, at the end, a decrease in overpressure to ordinary pressure, marked by a thinning of the line.
english.ng_28: Scratch tone produces a sound that combines white noise and overpressure.
english.ng_28_ex: It is executed by applying slight overpressure near the bridge.
english.ng_29: The seagull effect is a glissando with interspersed harmonics that simulates the sound of a seagull.
english.ng_29_ex: It is performed by executing the glissando as indicated, but maintaining the glissando position without proportional adjustment to sustain the harmonic. This makes the harmonics jump.
english.ng_30: The airy sound resembles a mix of air and white noise.
english.ng_30_ex: It is recommended to produce it by covering the strings and bowing with minimal pressure.
english.ng_31: The rim belly technique produces an airy and almost imperceptible sound.
english.ng_31_ex:
It is performed by bowing on the exterior of the instrument.

Although this technique produces a virtually inaudible sound, the visual aspect is very impactful, so it is recommended that the performer's gesture be more exaggerated than usual when playing it.
english.ng_32: The tailpiece technique produces different sonorities depending on the pressure and the instrument. Minimal pressure results in an airy sound; more pressure results in a deeper sound, and even more pressure can produce guttural sounds or specific tones, depending on the instrument.
english.ng_32_ex: The bowing should be performed on the tailpiece, and the sonority can also vary depending on the bowing position.
english.ng_33_ex: It is executed by forcefully tapping the strings with the fingers. Sometimes, using thimbles is recommended for a more precise sound.
english.ng_34: Hair glissando produces a rough sound.
english.ng_34_ex: For this technique, it is important to consider the horizontal direction of the hand on the bow (marked by the ascending or descending glissando) and the vertical direction of the bow on the string (marked by the arrow to the left of the technique).
english.ng_35: Strike the strings with the hand while keeping the hand on the strings.
english.ng_35_ex: In cases where the hand symbol is not filled in, the hand should not stay on the strings (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fX9-jddE2bY&t=507s).
english.ng_36: Stoppato or mute is an extended technique that produces a percussive sound, practically without tone, on the piano.
english.ng_36_ex: The piano strings must be dampened. In this case, an object will be required to keep the strings dampened for an extended period.
english.ng_37: This technique involves two notations: the representation of the güiro instrument (referencing its sonority) and the "x" on note heads, referencing the percussive, toneless sound of the result.
english.ng_37_ex: It is advisable to review Lachenmann's work "Guero," which develops this gesture.
english.ng_38: This technique involves two notations: the use of a guitar pick and bowing on the metallic part of the string holders. The result is a bright metallic sound.
english.ng_38_ex:
A 1.5mm pick is recommended.

If speed makes holding the pick unfeasible, using the fingernail is an option.
english.ng_39: This technique involves two notations: the use of a guitar pick and bowing at the end of the strings. The result is a very bright metallic sound.
english.ng_39_ex:
A 1.5mm pick is recommended.

If speed makes holding the pick unfeasible, using the fingernail is an option.
english.ng_40: Harmonic glissando produces a continuous and bright sonority.
english.ng_40_ex:
It can be performed using a shot glass, spatula, or any object that produces similar sonority.

The distance for performing the technique varies depending on the note and piano model.
english.ng_41_ex: With one hand, play as many notes as possible (both white and black keys) within the indicated range.
english.ng_42: The piano zones are represented by the notation Iz., IIz., IIIz., IV., corresponding to the zones shown in the image.
english.ng_42_ex:
Not all piano models have these zones equally defined or accessible, so performers are asked to approximate based on their instrument.

Using movable music stands inside the piano is advisable to avoid hindering access to internal techniques.
english.ng_43: The whammy bar, tremolo bar, or tremolo, temporarily alters the guitar's pitch.
english.ng_43_ex: It is important to consider the graphical gradation, which indicates the speed at which the gesture should be performed.
english.ng_44: Click sounds are short, percussive sonorities.
english.ng_44_ex: They are produced using a pick, striking the strings quickly to create a staccato sound.
english.ng_45: Palm mute is a technique that produces a muted sound from the strings.
english.ng_45_ex: It is performed by resting the picking hand on the guitar bridge.
english.ng_46: The 'behind the nut' technique produces crystalline sonorities.
english.ng_46_ex: It is performed by bowing near the end of the fingerboard, just before the tuning pegs, often accompanied by an arpeggiated gesture.
english.ng_47: The 'wild and crazy' technique produces the sound described by its name.
english.ng_47_ex: It is achieved by performing rapid, articulated overpressures.
english.ng_48: Slow-motion glissando produces a subtle sound.
english.ng_48_ex: It is achieved by performing the technique as indicated on all strings of the instrument.
english.ng_49: Slow-motion bowing produces a subtle sound.
english.ng_49_ex: It is achieved by performing the technique as indicated.
english.ng_50: The long irregular tremolo produces an unstable sonority.
english.ng_50_ex: It is achieved by alternating quickly and unevenly between the notes of the indicated chord.
english.ng_51: The technique 'looking at the audience' is part of the collection of performative techniques.
english.ng_51_ex: The gaze should be fixed on the audience until another technique indicates otherwise.
english.ng_52: The technique 'looking with a crazy face' is part of the collection of performative techniques.
english.ng_52_ex: The gaze should be fixed on the audience with an exaggerated facial expression until another technique indicates otherwise.
english.ng_53: The technique 'pause' is part of the collection of performative techniques.
english.ng_53_ex: The position should be held in pause until another technique indicates otherwise. It often precedes a play technique.
english.ng_54: The technique 'play' is part of the collection of performative techniques.
english.ng_54_ex: The performance should continue in an ordinary manner. It is often preceded by a pause technique.
